election_record.label: New Hampshire 1804 U.S. House of Representatives

overview.note: Only a handful of towns had their full results reported. The vast majority of towns only had the votes reported for each ticket as a whole.
The Official Results list 105,852 total votes with 10586 to make a choice.

The Official Results lists Samuel Tenney with 10988 votes, David Hough with 10979 votes, Thomas Thompson with 10977 votes, Silas Betton with 10977 votes, Caleb Ellis with 10972 votes, Nahum Parker with 10209 votes, Ezra Bartlett with 10174 votes, Thomas Cogswell with 10171 votes, Clement Storer with 10171 votes and Jedediah K. Smith with 10151 votes.
The votes from Atkinson, Bartlett, Derryfield, Dunstable, Eaton, Landaff and Sutton were rejected.
"There were only a few scattering votes, about 80. The average federal majority is about 803." Farmer's Museum (Walpole, NH). October 6, 1804.
"The scattering votes amounted to 83." Haverhill Observer (Haverhill, MA). October 2, 1804.

"A few vigorous Federalists in New Hampshire, however, rejecting the usual pessimism with which their colleagues accepted defeat and reasoning that organized effort should not necessarily be a Republican monopoly, decided to put up a strong fight for the congressional elections in August. Among these men who met secretly in Concord on July 4, were Senator Plumer, Thomas W. Thompson of Salisbury, a Harvard-bred attorney with whom young Daniel Webster was reading law, and William H. Woodward, a lawyer from Hanover and treasurer of Dartmouth College (fn: John Lord, A History of Hanover, N.H. (Hanover, N.H., 1928), 163.). The apparatus that they put together was even more sophisticated than Carrigain's Republican machine. Under themselves as a state committee, county committees were established which appointed agents in each town and each school district. Provisions were made to secure funds, to support the Federalist newspapers, to enlist new voters and to keep registers of all Federalists (fn: William Plumer, 'Proceedings of the Federalists in New Hampshire in 1804', 'Repository,' I:264-68, William Plumer Papers, New Hampshire State Library). Plumer, under the pseudonym 'Impartialis,' wrote a far from impartial Address to the Electors of New Hampshire, which was printed first in the newspapers and then in pamphlet form (fn: [Impartialis], An Address to the Electors of New Hampshire (Portsmouth, N.H., 1804), 3). The energy of the Federalist campaign surprised and enraged the Republicans. Gideon Granger wrote to Jefferson that their foes were 'making astonishing exertions.' (fn: Gideon Granger to Thomas Jefferson, September 2, 1804, folio 143, Jefferson Papers) The New Hampshire Gazette reported that Cheshire County Federalists were employing 'immense pecuiniary contributions, systematic caucausing, and incredible exertions.' (fn: Robinson, Jeffersonian Democracy, 64n) The result was eloquent testimony to the effectiveness of such tactics. The Federalist candidates won by an average majority of eight hundred votes, but even more remarkable was the fact that the total vote cast was almost double that of the previous congressional election." The Ninth State. 216-217.

"THE ELECTION. On Monday last the citizens of this State assembled in the respective towns to ballot for five persons to represent them in the Congress of the United States for two years from the 4th of March next. The meetings, in this county, were in general, very well attended, and the result has been equal to the general expectation. In this town, the votes were declared to be 222 for ... who comprised the Federal, or Washington Ticket--and 26 for ... who were the Democratic candidates. ... By comparing the votes given at this time with those given in March last for Governor, our readers will perceive the loss and gain of each party. In 28 towns in this county, the Federal gain has been 295, and the Democratic loss 40--making a difference of 335 in 5 months! The total gain in the towns returned is 190." The New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH), September 1, 1804.

"THE ELECTION. We present the following List of votes, given last week for members of Congress, with those given last spring for Governor. It will be seen there is not so many given now, as then. The federal decrease in the towns given below, has been 626; the republican decrease in the same towns is 1143." Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH), September 4, 1804.

"We this day hand to our readers the promised statement of votes for Representatives to Congress, from which they will be enabled to form a correct idea of the politics of this State. Neither Federalists or Republicans have at present much to boast of; the majorities, which ever way they turn, are small and if we may be permitted to hazard our opinion, need but the exertions of a few influential men, to become more decided.--It is to be hoped that the Citizens of New Hampshire will be guided in their final choice, by a due regard to their individual and collective happiness and safety, and that they will be carefull how they surrender their dearest rights; zealously shunning to commit them to mercenary or ambitious men--who, in due time, will become tyrants and a bane to their Country ... 21,760 votes being given, 10,886 constitute a majority; the federal candidates having 11,076 were chosen constitutionally by 190 votes, although their actual majority was 465." The Political Star (Portsmouth, NH), October 11, 1804.

sub_unit.name: Cheshire
sub_unit.note: "Our political foes may reasonably exclaim that 'Cheshire is the seat of Federalism.'" Farmer's Museum (Walpole, NH), September 8, 1804.

The Courier of New Hampshire (Concord, NH) lists the Federalist Ticket with 250 votes and the Republican Ticket with 14 votes.

sub_unit.name: Loudon
sub_unit.note: The Courier of New Hampshire (Concord, NH) and The New Hampshire Gazette (Portsmouth, NH) list the Federalist Ticket with 92 votes.
Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH) lists the Republican Ticket with 36 votes.

sub_unit.name: New Castle
sub_unit.note: The Courier of New Hampshire (Concord, NH), Portsmouth Oracle (Portsmouth, NH), Dartmouth Gazette (Hanover, NH) list the Republican Ticket with 42 votes.
The New Hampshire Gazette (Portsmouth, NH) lists the Republican Ticket with 45 votes.

sub_unit.name: Newmarket
sub_unit.note: The September 7, 1808 edition of the Dartmouth Gazette (Hanover, NH), in comparing the 1804 and 1808 elections lists 31 votes for the Federalist Ticket and 91 votes for the Republican Ticket in this election.
The Political Star (Portsmouth, NH) lists the Federalist Ticket with 36 votes.

sub_unit.name: North Hampton
sub_unit.note: The September 7, 1808 edition of the Dartmouth Gazette (Hanover, NH), in comparing the 1804 and 1808 elections lists 42 votes for the Federalist Ticket.

Portsmouth Oracle (Portsmouth, NH), The New Hampshire Gazette (Portsmouth, NH), Political Star (Portsmouth, NH) and The Sun. Dover Gazette and County Advertiser (Dover, NH) list the Federalist Ticket with 42 votes.

sub_unit.name: Northfield
sub_unit.note: The Political Observatory (Walpole, NH), Dartmouth Gazette (Hanover, NH) and The Albany Register (Albany, NY) list the Federalist Ticket with 14 votes and the Republican Ticket with 87 votes.
The New Hampshire Gazette (Portsmouth, NH) lists the Republican Ticket with 72 votes.
Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH) lists the Republican Ticket with 78 votes.

sub_unit.name: Northwood
sub_unit.note: The Farmer's Museum (Walpole, NH) and New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH) list the Federalist Ticket with 58 votes.

sub_unit.name: Nottingham
sub_unit.note: The September 7, 1808 edition of the Dartmouth Gazette (Hanover, NH), in comparing the 1804 and 1808 elections lists 19 votes for the Federalist Ticket and 60 votes for the Republican Ticket in this election.
The New Hampshire Gazette (Portsmouth, NH) lists the Republican Ticket with 60 votes.

sub_unit.name: Pembroke
sub_unit.note: The New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH) lists the Republican Ticket with 62 votes.

sub_unit.name: Pittsfield
sub_unit.note: The Political Observatory (Walpole, NH), Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH) and The Albany Register (Albany, NY) list the Federalist Ticket with 54 votes and the Republican Ticket with 100 votes.
The Political Star (Portsmouth, NH) and The Sun. Dover Gazette and County Advertiser (Dover, NH) list the Federalist Ticket with 54 votes and the Republican Ticket with 160 votes.
The New Hampshire Gazette (Portsmouth, NH) lists the Federalist Ticket with 54 votes and the Republican Ticket with 60 votes.
Portsmouth Oracle (Portsmouth, NH) lists the Federalist Ticket with 77 votes and the Republican Ticket with 79 votes.
The Farmer's Museum (Walpole, NH) and New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH) list the Federalist Ticket with 72 votes.

sub_unit.name: Plaistow
sub_unit.note: The Sun. Dover Gazette and County Advertiser (Dover, NH) lists the Republican Ticket with 35 votes.

sub_unit.name: Portsmouth
sub_unit.note: The Albany Register (Albany, NY) lists the Republican Ticket with 620 votes.
Portsmouth Oracle (Portsmouth, NH) lists the Republican Ticket with 627 votes.

sub_unit.name: Salem
sub_unit.note: Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH) lists the Federalist Ticket with 98 votes and the Republican Ticket with 53 votes.

sub_unit.name: Seabrook
sub_unit.note: The New Hampshire Gazette (Portsmouth, NH), Political Star (Portsmouth, NH) and The Sun. Dover Gazette and County Advertiser (Dover, NH) list the Republican Ticket with 11 votes and the Federalist ticket with no votes.

sub_unit.name: Stratham
sub_unit.note: Portsmouth Oracle (Portsmouth, NH), The New Hampshire Gazette (Portsmouth, NH) and Political Star (Portsmouth, NH) list the Republican Ticket with 90 votes.

sub_unit.name: Strafford
sub_unit.note: The above totals include the votes from Eaton, which were returned too late and therefore not counted.

sub_unit.name: Barnstead
sub_unit.note: The Courier of New Hampshire (Concord, NH), Political Observatory (Walpole, NH), Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH) and The Albany Register (Albany, NY) list the Republican Ticket with 111 votes.
The Sun. Dover Gazette and County Advertiser (Dover, NH) lists the Federalist Ticket with 14 votes and the Republican Ticket with 75 votes.

sub_unit.name: Barrington
sub_unit.note: The Farmer's Museum (Walpole, NH) and New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH) list the Federalist Ticket with 376 votes and the Republican Ticket with 40 votes.

sub_unit.name: Dover
sub_unit.note: The Farmer's Museum (Walpole, NH), Political Observatory (Walpole, NH), The New Hampshire Gazette (Portsmouth, NH), New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH), Political Star (Portsmouth, NH), Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH) and The Albany Register (Albany, NY) list the Republican Ticket with 123 votes.
Portsmouth Oracle (Portsmouth, NH) and the Dartmouth Gazette (Hanover, NH) list the Federalist Ticket with 90 votes.

sub_unit.name: Durham
sub_unit.note: The Farmer's Museum (Walpole, NH), Dartmouth Gazette (Hanover, NH), New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH), Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH) and The Sun. Dover Gazette and County Advertiser (Dover, NH) list the Republican Ticket with 96 votes.
The Political Observatory (Walpole, NH), The New Hampshire Gazette (Portsmouth, NH), Political Star (Portsmouth, NH) and The Albany Register (Albany, NY) list the Federalist Ticket with 46 votes.

sub_unit.name: Eaton
sub_unit.note: Rejected, not certified.

The Courier of New Hampshire (Concord, NH), New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH), Political Star (Portsmouth, NH) and The Sun. Dover Gazette and County Advertiser (Dover, NH) list the Republican Ticket with 75 votes.

The Political Observatory (Walpole, NH), Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH) and The Albany Register (Albany, NY) list the Federalist Ticket with 10 votes and the Republican Ticket with 42 votes, which should have been listed as the results for Effingham.

sub_unit.name: Effingham
sub_unit.note: The Political Observatory (Walpole, NH), Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH) and The Albany Register (Albany, NY) list the Federalist Ticket with 63 votes and the Republican Ticket with 45 votes.

sub_unit.name: Farmington
sub_unit.note: The Farmer's Museum (Walpole, NH), Political Observatory (Walpole, NH), The New Hampshire Gazette (Portsmouth, NH), New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH), Political Star (Portsmouth, NH), Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH) and The Albany Register (Albany, NY) list the Federalist Ticket with 26 votes and the Republican Ticket with 48 votes.

sub_unit.name: Gilmantown
sub_unit.note: The Farmer's Museum (Walpole, NH) and New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH) list the Republican Ticket with 87 votes.

sub_unit.name: Lee
sub_unit.note: The Courier of New Hampshire (Concord, NH) and Farmer's Museum (Walpole, NH) list the Republican Ticket with 51 votes.

sub_unit.name: Madbury
sub_unit.note: Portsmouth Oracle (Portsmouth, NH), The Courier of New Hampshire (Concord, NH) and Dartmouth Gazette (Hanover, NH) list the Federalist Ticket with 23 votes.

sub_unit.name: Meredith
sub_unit.note: The Courier of New Hampshire (Concord, NH), Farmer's Museum (Walpole, NH), Political Observatory (Walpole, NH), New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH), Dartmouth Gazette (Hanover, NH), Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH) and The Albany Register (Albany, NY) list the Federalist Ticket with 67 votes and the Republican Ticket with 84 votes.
Portsmouth Oracle (Portsmouth, NH) lists the Federalist Ticket with 67 votes.

sub_unit.name: Milton
sub_unit.note: The Dartmouth Gazette (Hanover, NH) list the Federalist Ticket with 29 votes.

sub_unit.name: New Durham
sub_unit.note: The Sun. Dover Gazette and County Advertiser (Dover, NH) lists the Federalist Ticket with 16 votes and the Republican Ticket with 19 votes.

sub_unit.name: New Hampton
sub_unit.note: The Courier of New Hampshire (Concord, NH), Portsmouth Oracle (Portsmouth, NH) and New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH) list the Republican Ticket with 15 votes.

sub_unit.name: Ossipee
sub_unit.note: The Courier of New Hampshire (Concord, NH) lists the Federalist Ticket with 26 votes.

sub_unit.name: Rochester
sub_unit.note: Portsmouth Oracle (Portsmouth, NH), Dartmouth Gazette (Hanover, NH) and The Sun. Dover Gazette and County Advertiser (Dover, NH) list the Federalist Ticket with 31 votes.
The Courier of New Hampshire (Concord, NH) lists the Republican Ticket with 105 votes.

sub_unit.name: Sanbornton
sub_unit.note: The Courier of New Hampshire (Concord, NH), Political Observatory (Walpole, NH), Dartmouth Gazette (Hanover, NH) and The Albany Register (Albany, NY) list the Republican Ticket with 107 votes.
Farmer's Cabinet (Amherst, NH) lists the Republican Ticket with 100 votes.
The Farmer's Museum (Walpole, NH) lists the Federalist Ticket with 98 votes.

sub_unit.name: Sandwich
sub_unit.note: The New Hampshire Gazette (Portsmouth, NH), New-hampshire Sentinel (Keene, NH) and Political Star (Portsmouth, NH) list the Federalist Ticket with 135 votes.

sub_unit.name: Wakefield
sub_unit.note: The Sun. Dover Gazette and County Advertiser (Dover, NH) lists the Federalist Ticket with 85 votes and the Republican Ticket with 32 votes.
